description: Anonymized examples of student insights from CARS Coach sessions. These examples show the format and quality of insights generated.

examples.sessionSummary: Student completed all phases with 80% MC accuracy. Struggled with identifying Move 2 language signals.

insights.text: Practice identifying gap-signaling language like 'however,' 'yet,' and 'nevertheless' in papers from your field—you missed some of these cues in the MC section.
Your paragraph analysis showed strong recognition of Move 1. Continue using phrases like 'increasingly important' and 'growing attention' in your own writing.
In Applied Linguistics, citation practices in Move 1 often cluster multiple references—observe how authors group citations to establish territory.
When writing your Move 3, try starting with 'This study investigates...' followed by a clear statement of your research questions.
insights.context: General Move 3 advice based on session

examples.sessionSummary: Strong performance throughout (90% MC). Excellent paragraph analysis. Some hesitation on structure questions.

insights.text: Your understanding of individual moves is strong. Now focus on transitions between moves—use connector phrases to guide readers smoothly.
Consider how your introduction can preview your theoretical framework—this is valued in Education research.
Your paragraph analysis was excellent! Apply this same analytical lens when revising your own introduction drafts.

examples.sessionSummary: Quick learner. 100% MC accuracy. Completed session in 15 minutes. Asked about applying CARS to methods sections.

insights.text: While CARS is designed for introductions, the move structure can loosely apply to other sections—literature reviews also establish territory and gaps.
In STEM writing, Move 2 often emphasizes methodological or technical limitations. Frame gaps in terms of what existing approaches cannot do.
Your quick grasp of CARS suggests you're ready to analyze multiple introductions in your field. Compare how different authors approach Move 1.

examples.sessionSummary: Needed extra MC questions (7 total). Improved from 40% to 80% accuracy. Breakthrough moment in short answer section.

insights.text: You showed great improvement once you connected Move 2 to 'creating tension'—keep using this narrative framing when writing introductions.
Review the difference between 'indicating a gap' and 'presenting a problem'—both work for Move 2 but have different rhetorical effects.
Social Sciences often have longer introductions with multiple Move cycles. Practice identifying where authors return to Move 1 within the same introduction.
Your final paragraph analysis showed solid understanding. Trust your instincts—you can identify moves when you take your time.

examples.sessionSummary: Engaged deeply with short answer questions. Provided thoughtful paragraph for analysis. Asked about disciplinary variation.

insights.text: In Humanities, Move 1 often includes theoretical positioning—consider where your theoretical lens fits in your introduction.
Your observation that 'gaps aren't always about missing data' is perceptive. Humanities often create niches through reinterpretation or new frameworks.
The argumentative structure in your paragraph analysis was well-identified. Now apply this same critical reading to your own drafts.

notes: Each insight should be specific and actionable
Positive insights are as important as corrective ones
Insights should build on observed student behavior
Avoid generic advice—personalize based on session data
